t: Job 31
I*pn have made a covenant with my eyes. How*ln then could I look at a young woman?
For*ln what portion would I have from God above, or*ln what inheritance from the Almighty on high?
Doesn’t*ln disaster come to the unjust and*ln misfortune to evildoers?
Does*ln he not see my ways and*ln number all my steps?
If*pn I have walked in falsehood or*ln my foot has rushed to deceit,
let*ln God weigh me on accurate scales, and*ln he will recognize my integrity.
If*pn my step has turned from the way, my*ln heart has followed my eyes, or*ln impurity has stained my hands,
let*ln someone else eat what I have sown, and*ln let my crops be uprooted.
If*pn my heart has gone astray over a woman or*ln I have lurked at my neighbor’s door,
let*ln my own wife grind grain for another man, and*ln let other men sleep with her.
For*ln that would be a disgrace; it*ln would be an iniquity deserving punishment.
For*ln it is a fire that consumes down to Abaddon; it*ln would destroy my entire harvest.
If*pn I have dismissed the case of my male or female servants when*ln they made a complaint against me,
what*ln could I do when God stands up to judge? How*ln should I answer him when he calls me to account?
Did*ln not the one who made me in the womb also make them? Did*ln not the same God form us both in the womb?
If*pn I have refused the wishes of the poor or*ln let the widow’s eyes go blind,
if*ln I have eaten my few crumbs alone without*ln letting the fatherless eat any of it —
for*ln from my youth, I raised him as his father, and*ln since the day I was born I guided the widow —
if*ln I have seen anyone dying for lack of clothing or*ln a needy person without a cloak,
if*ln he did not bless me while*ln warming himself with the fleece from my sheep,
if*ln I ever cast my vote against a fatherless child when*ln I saw that I had support in the city gate,
then*ln let my shoulder blade fall from my back, and*ln my arm be pulled from its socket.
For*ln disaster from God terrifies me, and*ln because of his majesty I could not do these things.
If*pn I placed my confidence in gold or*ln called fine gold my trust,
if*ln I have rejoiced because my wealth is great or*ln because my own hand has acquired so much,
if*ln I have gazed at the sun when it was shining or*ln at the moon moving in splendor,
so*ln that my heart was secretly enticed and*ln I threw them a kiss,
this*ln would also be an iniquity deserving punishment, for*ln I would have denied God above.
Have*pn I rejoiced over my enemy’s distress, or*ln become excited when trouble came his way?
I*ln have not allowed my mouth to sin by*ln asking for his life with a curse.
Haven’t*ln the members of my household said, “Who*ln is there who has not had enough to eat at Job’s table?”

Have*ln I covered my transgressions as others do by*ln hiding my iniquity in my heart

If*pn only I had someone to hear my case! Here*ln is my signature; let the Almighty answer me. Let*ln my Opponent compose his indictment.
I*ln would surely carry it on my shoulder and*ln wear it like a crown.
I*ln would give him an account of all my steps; I*ln would approach him like a prince.

if*ln I have consumed its produce without payment or*ln shown contempt for its tenants,
then*ln let thorns grow instead of wheat and*ln stinkweed instead of barley. The*p words of Job are concluded.
